title: How to add books between Kindle accounts - Quora

response.answer_text: In theory, you could scan the pages of a book, generate one long PDF file from all pages’ scans, and upload it to your Kindle library. Then read it on your Kindle. In practice, reading a PDF document on a Kindle is like trying to read a newspaper with a magnifying glass, having all space outside the magnifying glass obscured. It is so bothersome that I would honestly consider giving up reading altogether. By the way … As no idea is too dumb to be implemented, some publishers actually “convert” printed books this way to ebooks. They send the scan through OCR software (which tries to recognize all the characters) and publish the result as an ebook — with most of the errors of the OCR software uncorrected. Those are the ebooks where readers complain about the many typos that are not in the printed edition. Typical errors are “e” replaced by “c”, or “raffle” spelled as “rafAe”, because the software was confused by the printed book’s font, which merged the combination “fl” to a typographic ligature:

Not sure I’m understanding what you mean by “between”. If you mean between Kindle devices, it is a simple matter of just adding / downloading to the new device. If you mean two or more “accounts” …. ie. John Green’s account & John Grey’s account …. sorry, but that’s not allowed. If YOU are both of these people, you might appeal to Amazon to merge the accounts. If that is possible, I’m sure they’d require proof.
